Add olive oil to a Dutch oven or large pot over medium high heat. Add the chicken and cook for 10 minutes, then remove the chicken from the pan with a slotted spoon and set aside.
Add all the mushrooms and saute for 6 minutes. Reserve 2 tablespoons of cooked mushrooms for garnish if you desire.
Add onions, garlic, thyme, sage, Marsala wine, and saute 4 more minutes.
Next, add the chicken stock and bring to a simmer. Then stir in the chicken and simmer 10 minutes uncovered.
Remove the thyme stems from the pot and discard. Whisk in the cream cheese, Parmesan cheese and Monterey jack cheese until smooth.
You can pan fry the reserved mushrooms in a little olive oil to use for garnish.
Garnish with extra mushrooms, sour cream, Monterey jack cheese, and parsley.
Preheat your waffle iron, spray with non stick cooking spray and set aside.
In a large bowl whisk together the flour, baking powder, sugar, salt, and cinnamon.
In a medium bowl beat the egg whites with a hand mixer until stiff peaks form. Set aside.
In a separate medium bowl mix together the egg yolks, vegetable oil, milk, and vanilla extract.
Add the egg yolk mixture to the dry ingredients and mix well.
Fold in the egg whites.
Pour the batter onto your hot waffle iron and cook according to manufacturer's directions**
Serve immediately with butter, syrup, powdered sugar or any other favorite toppings.
Brown the beef and sausage until 80% cooked through. Do it in 1lb increments to not crowd the pan. Lightly salt the meats while cooking.
After browning the beef, strain the oil and put 2 tbsp back in the pan.
Add onions, carrots, and celery and cook until onions become translucent.
Add garlic and cook until onions are lightly caramelized.
Add tomato paste and cook for 5 minutes to get the raw tomato taste out.
Add beef back into the pot and mix. Stir in 2 tbsp dried chili flakes and 2 cups beef stock and mix.
Once it has reduced to a thick sauce, add 1.5 cups milk and reduce down again.
At this point, you should add salt, pepper, and Italian seasoning to your liking. I typically add 1.5 tsp salt, 0.5 tsp pepper, and 0.5 tsp Italian seasoning.
Take pot off heat. Mix two egg yolks together in a separate bowl and add to the pot. Stir quickly to avoid curdling the egg.
Mix two whole eggs in cottage cheese and set aside.

Ladle the meat sauce onto the bottom of a casserole dish, then lay down noodles, then another layer of meat sauce, then cottage cheese, shredded cheese, and parsley. Repeat layering until the dish is full. The last layer should be just meat sauce and cottage cheese.
Preheat oven to 350F and bake for 45 minutes. You may want to place a baking tray below the casserole dish to prevent spillage.
Preheat oven to 400F. Add another layer of parsley and finally a thick layer of cheese to the top. Bake for another 15 minutes.
Let stand for 20 minutes before cutting and serving.
Boil beef bones and bone-in beef for 8 minutes.
Wash off beef under cold tap water. Make sure fat from bones is trimmed off or else you get oily broth.
Place oven rack on topmost notch and high broil onion and ginger until partially blackened.
Place 5 quarts of filtered water in pot. Place all ingredients (not for serving) in the pot.
Simmer for 6 to 10 hours with lid off. More time for more flavor.
Skim off any scum or fat pieces.
Stir 4 or so times during the entire process.
When pot gets down to 4 quarts, fill back to 5. You should end with 4 quarts of water.
Take pho off heat.
Taste broth. Add 1 or 2 tbsp more of fish sauce and sometimes soy sauce, depending on flavor.
Boil rice noodles until al dente (1 to 2 minutes).
Boil thin beef for 30 seconds until lightly browned.
Plate bowl with noodles, meat, herbs, and anything else.
Pour broth through skimmer over bowl.
Serve and eat.

Equipment:
8 quart Instant Pot
8 quart stock pot
1 XL bowl to eat ramen
Spice Grinder (best) or blender or pestle and mortar
Fine mesh strainer (two for best results)
Immersion Blender
1 glass bottle for garlic oil (I reused an old soy sauce bottle)
2 Large storage containers
1 for broth; 1 for chashu
4 small storage containers
Tare, chashu broth, corn, mushrooms
1 small zip-loc bag for eggs
Funnel not required, but helpful
Large colander for pork bones
Small pot for cooking noodles
Small colander for for noodles
Knife, cutting board
2 wooden spoons/flippers for flipping chashu
Cling wrap
Broth:
1 pound pigs trotters (not hocks!) (skin on)
Notes: Pig trotters don’t have a lot of flavor and are used as a source of gelatin to give the broth a thick and smooth mouthfeel
4 pounds pork neck bones
Notes: Pork bones are your main source of pork flavor for the broth. You can use any kind of pork bone as long as it contains marrow. Neck bones are the easiest to find at American supermarkets. Just make sure that your bones do not have a lot of excess meat on them. A little bit of meat on the neck bones is totally fine, but it shouldn’t be so much that you could make a meal of it.
1 bunch green onion, cut in quarters
1 large yellow onion, cut in half
2 shallots, cut in half
2 3-inch knob ginger, peeled
4 garlic cloves, peeled and crushed
16 oz Sliced Mushrooms
Notes: Wood ear mushrooms and shiitake mushrooms are traditional in ramen, but I REALLY DISLIKED the dried kind. If you can find them fresh then that’s perfect, but if not, go for portabella mushrooms.
3.5 (or more) quarts filtered water
Chashu:
4 lbs pork
Notes: Traditionally pork belly, but bone-in pork butt or pork shoulder much cheaper and still just as good.
1/2 cup soy sauce
3/4 cup mirin
Notes: Aji Mirin translates to tastes-like Mirin. Usually Aji Mirin contains Corn Syrup. Real Aji Mirin will be darker and thicker than Aji Mirin and either doesn’t contain corn syrup (best!) or contains little corn syrup. Try your best to get real mirin!
1/3 cup filtered water
1 cup rice wine (1/2 cup sake, 1/2 cup shiao tsing wine)
2 inch knob ginger, peeled
1 bunch green onion
4-5 cloves garlic, crushed
1 tsp chinese 5 spice (Below to make a lot; grind spices)
2 teaspoons Sichuan peppercorns
5 to 6 star anise
1/2 teaspoon ground cloves
1 tablespoon ground Chinese cinnamon
1 tablespoon ground fennel seeds
½ tbsp black pepper
½ tbsp white pepper
¼ cup brown sugar
Tare:
1 cup filtered water
3 2-square inch pieces kombu
10 pieces sliced dried shiitake mushroom
1/2 cup bonito flakes
3/4 cup soy sauce
1/4 cup + 2 Tbsp mirin
1/4 cup chashu braising liquid after chashu has cooked
Notes: This is not traditional, but it tastes better
A lot of salt, to taste
Black Garlic Oil
1/2 cup dried garlic chips
Notes: I actually couldn’t find dried garlic chips, so I sliced fresh garlic in 25-cent thick slices and it worked well. I’ve just read that the process is faster and better with dried garlic chips, but in my experience fresh garlic works fine too.
1/2 cup canola oil
1/2 cup sesame oil
Notes: This is the “aroma oil”. This is what puts “black” in “tonkotsu black”. You can replace it with other aroma oils, such as chili oil or scallion oil.
Toppings:
Straight ramen noodles (Not the curly noodles unless you really want to)
Chopped Green onions (as THIN as possible)
Soft Boiled Egg (Recipe below)
16 oz Sliced Mushrooms (These are the same mushrooms as listed in the broth, so don’t buy any extra mushrooms)
2 small rectangles nori
Notes: Get thick Nori. I got thin Nori one time and it completely disintegrated into my ramen. Yuck!
Sweet whole kernel corn
Eggs
Soft Boiled Egg (6.5 mins)
3 tbsp soy sauce
1 tbsp mirin
½ cup filtered water

Day 1:
Chashu:
Put all Chashu ingredients in a large bowl and mix. Place pork of choice in bowl and cover with marinade. Marinate pork for at least 24 hours in the fridge. Flip pork half-way through to evenly marinate.
Tare:
Tare is the seasoning of your ramen to give it salty and umami components.
In small storage container, put in 1 cup filtered water, 3 2-square inch pieces of kombu, and 10 slices of shiitake mushrooms and get everything wet. Put the lid on the container and steep overnight in the fridge for 24 hours.
Black Garlic Oil:
Prepare a plate with some paper towels on it to put the fried garlic on.
Heat ½ cup canola oil in saucepan on medium heat.
Once hot, put ½ cup garlic chips in oil. You will want to stir every 30 seconds or so to make sure the garlic browns evenly.
You will need to watch for the color of the garlic and take out ¼ of the garlic onto the plate in four different intervals based on the color of the garlic: Light brown, brown, dark brown, black (yes literally black, but not a second more or else it will turn to char!)
You should now have four piles of different colored garlic. Place all garlic in a spice grinder and grind until you get very small granules, like ground coffee. 
Mix the ground garlic with the canola oil from the pot and ½ cup fresh sesame oil and let the garlic rest in the oil for about an hour.
Using a fine mesh strainer, or two if you can, along with a funnel, strain and pour garlic oil into glass bottle and store it in the fridge for up to 3 months.
Tonkotsu Broth:
You could technically do this on day two, but that just leaves a lot of work for day two.
Take 1lb trotters and 4 lb pork bones out of fridge so that they can warm up a bit.
In large stock pot, fill about ⅔ way with tap water and bring it up to a boil. This takes a while to boil, so placing a lid on top will make it boil faster. You must be patient and wait for a rolling boil because when you throw the bones in, it will drastically lower the temperature of the water.
Place trotters and bones in boiling water, stir them around, and place lid on top of pot until it comes back to a boil. Remove lid and then start timer for 10 minutes to blanch the bones.
Some “scum” will start to form at the top of the water. Scum is the pink/brown/white thick foam that will rise to the surface of the water. About 5 minutes into the boiling process after some of the scum has coagulated, take a fine mesh strainer to skim off the scum and then mix around the bones again. After another 5 minutes, skim the scum again, mix the bones up to release anymore scum, and then immediately drain into large colander.
Thoroughly rinse bones in cold water and use fingers to scrape off any excess scum or yucky dark bits that you don’t want in your broth. You’ll want to be pretty OCD during this step to have a nice white milky broth at the end.
Place trotters and pork bones into instant pot and fill with 3.5 quarts of filtered water. Do your best to use filtered water since 99% of the broth is water. Bad water = bad broth.
Put lid on instant pot and pressure cook on the meat/stew setting on low (use the adjust button to switch to low) for 90 minutes.
While this goes, prepare your aromatics per the ingredient list instructions.
After 90 minutes, depressurize instant pot, open it, and leave the lid off for these next steps.
Put two more cups of water into instant pot.
Place all aromatics in and give everything a mix. Turn instant pot on meat/stew setting on Normal for 60 minutes to bring everything to a rolling boil. Stir occasionally to prevent anything sticking to the bottom. Note: The rolling boil creates an emulsion between the water and the oil to create that white, creamy, thick tonkotsu broth.
After 60 minutes, your broth should be white and creamy looking. If it didn’t turn white and cloudy, then you didn’t boil it hot enough. If it’s more of a brown color, then you didn’t clean the bones well enough or there was too much meat on the bones. But don’t expect to get a perfect white broth. A bit of beige color is passable.
Use a slotted spoon, not a fine strainer, to take out all the big bits in the broth, such as the bones, trotters, aromatics. Pick out mushrooms and place them in a storage container for toppings later.
While the broth is still very hot, use an immersion blender all around the pot to blend up any tiny chunks left (for flavor) and more importantly to create an even stronger emulsion.
Use two fine mesh strainers to double strain the broth into a large storage bowl, either metal or thick plastic that is resistant to heat. If you don’t have two fine mesh strainers, then make sure to strain the broth twice. There should be a lot of pulp in the broth and you’ll need to work the liquid through. Once you have worked all the liquid through and all you have left is pulp, you can do one of two things based on personal preference. You can squeeze the pulp dry to extract as much liquid and flavor out of the pulp as possible, or if you want a super white broth, then don’t squeeze the pulp. Since I’m not trying to sell this ramen nor am I trying to impress anyone with my super white broth, I choose to squeeze my pulp for extra flavor.
Place lid or plastic wrap on bowl and set in fridge immediately to cool off to prevent any bacteria from forming. Some people like to put the broth bowl in an even larger bowl filled with ice water to cool down the broth quickly to prevent as little bacteria growth as possible, but unless you are freezing the broth (which you can do) to store it for a long time, I wouldn't be too concerned about bacteria growth.

Check your tonkotsu broth. If it is white and jiggles/feels like jello, then you did a great job. Keep it in the fridge for now.
Chashu:
Put pork and entire marinade into large stock pot.
Braise pork on a low simmer for one hour per pound of pork. Flip every hour and stir marinade occasionally. Make sure there are no aromatics underneath the pork or else they may burn.
After cooking, transfer pork to large container with a small amount of marinade just to keep moist. Transfer the rest of the marinade to a storage container. Place pork and marinade in fridge to cool.
Soft Boiled Egg:
Right after your pork has begun to cook, start the eggs because they will need time to marinate. You could make the eggs on day one and marinate overnight, but it could get a bit too salty.
Bring small pot to rapid boil before putting in eggs.
Boil 6 eggs for 6 minutes and 30 seconds exactly.
Take pot over to sink and pour cold water over the eggs until they have cooled down enough for you to peel them.
Place eggs into small zip-loc bag and pour the marinade ingredients into bag.
Squeeze as much air out of the bag as possible and place eggs in fridge.
Tare:
Ideally, you should time your tare to be done at the same time that your chashu is done. It takes about 20 minutes to make the tare.
Place tare liquid in saucepan and squeeze out liquid from kombu and mushrooms as much as you can.
Slowly bring tare to a low simmer.
Once it is at a simmer, cut the heat and add in ½ cup bonito flakes and steep for 10 minutes. You can keep the pot on the burner, just turn the heat off and make sure the liquid isn’t bubbling.
Using fine mesh strainer, strain the tare into storage container and squeeze liquid from pulp. 
Mix in remaining tare ingredients. Season with salt to make it too salty. It should be so salty that it stings your tongue, but still very tasty. This will be the only source of salt in your entire dish, so it should be very salty. If you are concerned that you might make it too salty, then be conservative and you can add extra salt to your ramen at the end. Place in fridge.
Assembly:
Finally it’s time to eat! Get your large ramen bowl and place in a as much tonkotsu broth as you want. I store my broth in a round bowl and it cools solid, so I cut out a “pie” sized piece into my bowl.
Put bowl in microwave for about 2 minutes to melt the broth.
Boil small pot of water and boil about a half-handful of noodles for 4 minutes. Strain noodles and shake off as much water as you can.
Slice chashu to your preference. Add thinly sliced green onions. Add corn. Add mushrooms. Add 2-3 tablespoons of tare. Add 1 tablespoon of chashu marinade. Add ½ to 1 tablespoon of black garlic oil. Taste the soup. If it isn’t salty enough and you have already added in 3 tablespoons of tare, then your tare isn’t salty enough. Don’t add more than 3 tablespoons of tare or else you won’t be able to taste the pork broth anymore. Just add some more salt to your ramen and add more salt to the tare for next time.
Place ramen back in microwave to heat until everything is super hot.
Add in your noodles and both halves of an egg. Microwave for 30 more seconds, but not anymore or else you’ll start to cook your egg.
Pat yourself on the back for a job well done.

Cook pasta noodles and set aside. I recommend salting the water that the pasta cooks in and slightly undercooking the pasta because it will be cooked the rest of the way when we bring it all together.
If you can’t find thinly sliced meat, then use your fist (or rolling pin or mallet) to flatten the steaks to about 1/4" thick. Slice into bite-sized strips, discarding excess fat.
Sprinkle meat with a pinch of salt and pepper.
Heat 1 tbsp oil in a large skillet over high heat.
Scatter half the beef in the skillet evenly around the pan. Sear for 30 seconds on each side.
Immediately remove onto a plate. Don't worry about pink bits and that it will be raw inside.
Add remaining 1 tbsp oil and repeat with remaining beef. Immediately remove onto a plate
Turn heat down to medium high and add butter to melt.

Add onions. Cook for 1 minute. Then add mushrooms. About half-way through the onion and mushroom cooking process, add in the garlic. Cook until onion is lightly caramelized and the mushrooms are golden brown.
Deglaze with dry white wine and scrape bottom of pan to get all the golden bits off.
Whisk in 2 tbsp flour into beef broth and make sure everything is dissolved.
Pour in beef broth mix.
Add sour cream, mustard, worcestershire sauce, and cream of mushroom soup. Stir until incorporated (don't worry if it looks split, sour cream will "melt" as it heats).
Bring to simmer, then reduce heat to medium low. Once it thickens to the consistency of pouring cream (3 - 5 minutes), adjust salt and pepper to taste.
Add beef back in (including plate juices) and mix. Then add in pasta noodles. Simmer for about 2 minutes and then remove from stove.
Serve, sprinkled with chives if desired.
To make Ghee, simmer unsalted butter on low in a saucepan for 25-30 minutes until clear. Strain using a coffee filter, cheesecloth, or mesh strainer.
Place the olive oil, garlic, chilies, onion, and ginger in a blender and purée until smooth.
Heat ghee in a large dutch oven over medium-high. Add the onion purée and cook until the mixture darkens slightly and softens, about 15 minutes.
Add the tomato paste, turmeric, chili powder, garam masala, coriander, and cumin and cook for 5 minutes, or until dark and sticky.
Add in 1/4 cup water. Using a wooden spoon, scrape up any browned bits at the bottom of the pan.

Stir in the tomato puree, 1 tsp salt, and fenugreek leaves and increase the heat to high. Bring to a boil, then reduce the heat to maintain a simmer. Cover and cook, stirring occasionally, until thick, about 1 hour. Add the chicken and cook until the chicken is cooked through, about 15 minutes more.
Add the cream and 1 stick butter and stir to combine. Season with ½ tsp salt (more or less to taste) and serve garnished with fresh cilantro with steamed Jasmine rice.
Note: This is a spicy dish. Use ½ the amount of Thai chili and sichuan peppercorns, and whole chilis if you want it more mild.
To marinate the chicken: Combine chicken pieces, Shaoxing wine, soy sauce, 1 beaten egg, and cornstarch in a medium-sized bowl. Mix well and marinate for 15 minutes.
For the spice mix: Combine all the spice mix ingredients in a big bowl.

When you’re ready, strain the chicken pieces to drain any excess marinade. Add a ¼ of the chicken coating to a one-gallon zip-lock bag. Pour the rest of the chicken coating on top. Close the bag and shake it up to coat the inside of the bag. Pour all the chicken inside the bag. Shake the bag vigorously until all the chicken has been coated. Make sure to break apart any pieces that may be stuck together. Pour the chicken back out in a dry bowl.
To cook the stir fry: Add ¾ oil to a large wok and preheat the oil to 450F.

When oil is hot, cook the chicken in batches to prevent crowding and sticking. Typically 3 batches is sufficient. Break apart any chicken that is stuck together and let it cook on one side until dark brown and crispy. Flip it over and let it cook until dark brown. Use a slotted spoon to remove the chicken and place it on a plate.

After all the chicken has cooked, strain the oil with a fine mesh strainer. Add 2 tbsp of the strained oil back into the pot. Add the Sichuan peppercorns. Cook for 5 mins on medium-low to bring out the aroma.
Add the garlic, ginger, green onions, and bowl of spice mix with the peppers. Cook until green onions begin to darken.
Return the cooked chicken into the pot to mix and warm the chicken.
Turn off the heat and add the cilantro and mix well.
Serve in a large bowl with side of rice.
In a cold skillet, add 1 tbsp olive oil and 1 tbsp butter and turn heat to medium-high.
When the pan heats and the butter has melted, add raw beef to pan, give it a stir to coat with olive oil and butter, and then add ½ cup Mexican ground beef seasoning.

Brown beef until medium rare for about 6-8 minutes. Strain the beef using a slotted spoon and set aside for later. You should still see bits of pink! The beef will cook the rest of the way in the oven.
Place diced onions in the same skillet and lightly caramelize onions in beef fat. If there is too much oil/fat, then drain accordingly. Set onions aside for later.
Preheat oven to 350F
On a clean counter or wax/parchment paper, set out all tortillas
Spread refried beans over tortillas as if it was pizza sauce
Add cooked ground beef first, then layer with onion, corn, tomatoes, green chilis, and a small amount of cheese to act as glue. We will put the majority of cheese on top.
Roll tortillas tight!!!

Spray the baking dish with cooking oil and place in enchiladas. The enchiladas should be touching each other, but not so tight that they are overflowing. WIth 10 tortillas, I can fit 6 in a large baking dish and 4 in a smaller one.
Tip: Pour enchilada sauce in a large measuring cup that has a spout for easy pouring.

Lightly, but completely, cover the enchiladas with enchilada sauce, but don’t use all the sauce. You want to use a light amount at first so that they crisp up in the oven. If you add too much sauce, then the enchiladas become soggy and not great.
Bake for 30 minutes on 350F

Take the dish out of the oven. The enchiladas should be completely dry on top. If they aren’t dry, then you added too much sauce. Now add another, slightly heavier, layer of enchilada sauce on top. Then add however much cheese to the top that you’d like. I usually end up using ½ - ⅔ lbs of cheese in total.
Bake for 10 more minutes
Cool for at least 10 minutes before serving. Serve with Mexican Rice if you prefer, but they’re great on their own!

Fill large bowl with cold water and about 4 tbsp salt. Place chicken in saltwater and rub the chicken to clean it. Strip off fat from all the top sides of the chicken. Fat on bottom can usually stay since it mostly minimal. We want funk-less chicken.

Take chicken out of bowl and pat dry. Score the chicken with a knife about ¼ inch deep and 1 inch apart to hold the marinade. You can also just stab the chicken multiple times. I like to peel away the skin and score only the meat and then cover the chicken back up.

In a food processor or blender, blend all vegetables, peppers (seeds and white pulp removed), seasonings, and spices to create the jerk marinade until smoothie consistency. You don’t want chunky or soupy.

In another large bowl, pour in the jerk marinade and drench the chicken with jerk marinade and work marinade into the chicken. Note: this marinade is really spicy and can burn hands with open wounds. In general, best to use gloves.
Cover top of bowl with plastic wrap and refrigerate for 4 - 24 hours
After marinating, preheat oven to 425F. You can also do it in the air fryer (steam and crisp mode) at 380F for 13 mins)

Take chicken out of the marinating bowl and brush off excess marinade from the skin-side of the chicken to allow for a crispier skin. Place the chicken onto a baking pan spaced evenly apart. Make sure there is not too much liquid in the pan or you’ll end up boiling your chicken. There should be a very thin layer. No more than ⅛ inch of liquid. Just enough to not be completely evaporated during cooking.
Bake chicken for 22 minutes on middle oven rack. Chicken should reach 165F.

While the chicken is baking, pour the excess marinade in a sauce pan and cook the marinade on a low simmer. This will kill the bacteria of the chicken and cook down the marinade to make it thicker. Simmer for at least 10 minutes, but you may want to cook it more depending on how thick you like your sauce.
Take the chicken out of the oven and let it rest for 5 minutes. Plate your chicken and spread your jerk sauce over the chicken to your liking.
Serve with Caribbean Coconut Rice and plantains or whatever you like.
Heat the oil in a large dutch oven or a heavy bottom pot over medium-high heat.
Whisk in the flour until combined and smooth.

Switch to a wooden spoon and continuously stir for 15-22 minutes or until the roux darkens to just past a deep peanut butter color. Do not let the roux burn! (if you smell it burning, you will need to throw is out, clean the pot, and start over, unfortunately there’s just no saving burnt roux!)
Stir in the onions, bell peppers, and celery and continue to cook for about 8-10 minutes or until the veggies soften, stirring as needed so the vegetables don’t stick.
Add the garlic, andouille sausage (if using tofurky, do not add yet), and bay leaves. Continue to cook for an additional 1-2 minutes until the garlic is nice and fragrant.

Add the cajun seasoning, tabasco sauce, and cayenne, chicken broth, and stewed tomatoes and bring to a high simmer before lowering the heat to medium-low, covering and simmering for 15-20 minutes. It may look soupy, but it will thicken slightly.
If Using Tofurky: Add a teaspoon of oil to a skillet over medium high heat. Add the slices and cook for a quick 90 seconds (turning half way) just to sear the outside before adding to the gumbo.

Add the shrimp and tofurky (if using) to the gumbo, give it a stir, put lid back on, and allow to continue to simmer for an additional 10-15 minutes or until the shrimp is opaque and the veggies have softened. Taste and season with salt and pepper as desired.
Add the gumbo filé and stir. Remove bay leaves before serving.
Serve warm with white rice or quinoa with sliced scallions on top.

recipe_instructions.summary: Fry the plantain until it is cooked through. 2-3 minutes
Extract the plantains from the oil
Press the plantains in a tortilla press to flatten them out
Once flattened, return plantains to the and cook for another 2 minutes
Remove tostones from oil onto rack. Sprinkle with sea salt

recipe_instructions.text: For the Cupcakes:
Preheat the oven to 350F. Line two 12-cup muffin pans with cupcake liners.
In a medium bowl, whisk together the flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt.

In a large mixing bowl or the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with the paddle attachment, beat the butter on medium speed until creamy. Add the sugar and beat until very light and fluffy, about 5 minutes.
Add the eggs, one at a time, beating until fully incorporated before adding the next. Stop and scrape down the bowl between each egg. Beat in the vanilla.
Stir together the sour cream and whole milk in a measuring cup or medium mixing bowl.

With the mixer on low speed, gradually add a third of the flour mixture to the butter mixture followed by half of the sour cream mixture. Repeat, alternating between the flour and sour cream. Scrape down the bowl. Beat in the chopped strawberries and food coloring, if using. Divide the batter among the cupcake liners. (About ¼ cup per liner.)

Bake one pan at a time for 20 to 25 minutes or until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean. Let cool for a few minutes in the pan, then remove the cupcakes and continue cooling on a wire rack.
For the Strawberry Buttercream:
In a large mixing bowl or the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with the whisk attachment, beat the butter and salt on medium speed until very creamy and pale, about 5 minutes.

With the mixer on low speed, gradually add in the powdered sugar and strawberry puree* until fluffy combined. Stope and scrape down the bowl as needed. Add the vanilla. Increase speed to medium and beat until fluffy and very spreadable, about 1 minute.

Transfer to a piping bag fitted with a decorative tip and pipe the frosting on top of the cooled cupcakes. Garnish with fresh strawberries, if desired. Cupcakes can be stored in an airtight container at room temperature without the garnish for up to 3 days or refrigerated for up to 1 week.

Prepare and cook ingredients as below. - For meat, mix the beef mince with the meat sauce listed above. Marinate the meat for about 30 mins while you are working on other ingredients to enhance the flavour. Add some cooking oil into a wok and cook the meat on medium high to high heat. It takes about 3 to 5 mins to thoroughly cook it.- Mix the bibimbap sauce ingredients in a bowl.- Cook spinach and bean sprouts per linked recipe.- Rinse, peel and julienne the carrots. Add some cooking oil and 1/4 tsp of fine sea salt in a wok and cook the carrots on medium high to high heat for 2 to 3 mins.- Clean/rinse the shiitake mushrooms and thinly slice them. Add some cooking oil and 1/4 tsp of fine sea salt in a wok and cook the mushrooms on medium high to high heat until they are all cooked. (It takes 2 to 3 mins.)- Make fried eggs. (While sunny side up is common, you can make them per your preference.)
Put the rice into a bowl and add the meat, assorted vegetables, seasoned seaweed, bibimbap sauce, and the egg on top of the rice. Serve.
To eat, mix the ingredients in the bowl, and enjoy!
Chop all veggies except the habanero. Prepare your seasonings
Coat your chicken with the garlic, oregano, and salt
Heat your pot to high heat.

Add cooking oil to hot pan. 
Immediately add chicken and start to brown. Stir often.
Once browned, add the vegetables and stir in.
Cook for a couple of minutes. Then add water to cover the ingredients. 
Cover with banana leaves and then put lid on the pot.
Reduce heat slightly and boil the stew for 30 minutes.
Step 1: Cook the Potatoes
Boil the potatoes with their skins on until fork-tender, about 20 minutes.
Drain and let them cool slightly before peeling.
Tip: Keeping the skins on while boiling prevents excess moisture, ensuring lighter gnocchi.
Step 2: Mash the Potatoes
Use a potato ricer or masher to create a light, fluffy texture.
Spread the mashed potatoes on a clean surface and let them cool completely.
Tip: Avoid over-mashing to prevent a gummy texture.
Step 3: Make the Dough
Sprinkle the flour evenly over the potatoes.
Make a well in the center, crack the egg into it, and add salt.
Gently mix with a fork until just combined.
Tip: Do not overwork the dough—knead lightly until it just comes together.
Step 4: Shape the Gnocchi
Divide the dough into four pieces.
Roll each piece into a rope about 1/2 inch thick.
Cut into bite-sized pieces.
Press each piece gently against the back of a fork to create ridges.
Tip: Lightly flour your hands and work surface to prevent sticking.
Step 5: Cook the Gnocchi
Bring a large pot of salted water to a rolling boil.
Drop the gnocchi in batches, stirring gently.
Once they float to the top, cook for 30 seconds, then remove with a slotted spoon.
Tip: Avoid overcrowding the pot—cook in small batches for even cooking.

To make the Champagne Vinaigrette, in a blender, combine the vinegar, sugar, mustard, shallot, and garlic and pulse until the shallot is minced. With the machine running, add the canola oil in a thin, steady stream to form an emulsion. Season to taste with salt and pepper. Set Aside.
Prepare a hot fire in a charcoal grill, or preheat a gas grill on high
Place the corn on the grill and grill, turning as needed, until nicely browned on all sides, about 10 minutes. Remove from the grill and let cool until easy to handle.

Working with 1 ear at a time, stand it upright, stem end down, on a cutting board. Using a sharp knife, cut downward between the kernels and the cob, removing the kernels and rotating the cob a quarter turn after each cut. Discard the cobs, scoop the kernels into a bowl, and set aside.

To make the Roasted Garlic Chicken, place a chicken thigh between 2 sheets of plastic wrap. Using a flat meat mallet, pound gently, beginning from the center and working out toward the edge, until the thigh is about 1/2 inch thick. Transfer to a bowl. Repeat with the remaining thighs.
Add the roasted garlic, Worcestershire sauce, Tabasco sauce, salt, and pepper to the chicken and mix gently. Cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least 2 hours or up to 8 hours.

In a large nonstick skillet over medium-high heat, heat the olive oil. Carefully add the chicken thighs, skin side down, and cook until the skin is a deep golden brown, about 5 minutes. Turn the thighs over and cook until the undersides are lightly browned and the juices run clear when the meat is pierced with a knife, about 3 minutes longer. Transfer to a platter.

To serve, in a large bowl, combine the corn, tomatoes, and arugula. Add the vinaigrette, toss gently to coat evenly, and season to taste with salt and pepper. Transfer the salad to chilled plates, shaping the ingredients into a mound.
Using a sharp knife, slice each chicken thigh into 6 or 7 pieces. Fan out a sliced thigh on each salad. Serve immediately.
Combine all ingredients in a bread machine or stand mixer. Knead for 5–10 minutes until a tight ball forms.
Place the dough in a warm area and let it rise for 1 hour.
Punch down the dough to remove air bubbles. For a loaf, form into a ball and place into a loaf pan. For rolls, divide into about 9–12 balls and place on a cookie sheet.
Cover and let rise for another hour.
Bake at 350°F. For a loaf, bake for about 23 minutes. For rolls, bake for about 12 minutes or until golden.
Optional: Brush rolls with melted butter and sprinkle with sea salt after baking.

In a large, deep-sided skillet over medium-high heat, heat oil. Season chicken all over with salt and pepper. Arrange chicken in skillet skin side down and cook, turning occasionally, until browned, about 5 minutes per side. Transfer chicken to a plate.

Reduce heat to medium. In same skillet, cook onion, stirring occasionally, until softened, about 5 minutes. Add garlic and cook, stirring, until fragrant, about 1 minute more. Add rice and cook, stirring frequently, until slightly toasted and fragrant, about 2 minutes. Add chiles and cook, scraping up any browned bits on bottom of pan. Add broth, oregano, and cumin; season with salt and pepper. Return chicken to skillet and bring to a boil, then cover and reduce heat to low. Simmer, stirring occasionally, until rice is cooked and chicken is cooked through, 12 to 15 minutes. Transfer chicken to a clean plate.
Add cheese and sour cream to skillet and stir until melted. Stir in cilantro.
Return chicken to skillet. Serve with lime wedges alongside.

Generously spray the bottom and sides of a 9×13-inch glass or ceramic baking pan with nonstick cooking spray. (I do not suggested a metal pan, as it can affect the taste of the marshmallows.) Sift the confectioners’ sugar and cornstarch together into a bowl and sprinkle some of it very lightly all around the pan, to dust it. Set the remaining sugar/cornstarch mixture aside.

Place the gelatin and 1/2 cup water in the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment. (Or, if using a handheld mixer, a regular large mixing bowl.) Whisk/beat on low speed for 1 minute to briefly combine. Allow to sit as you cook the sugar syrup—no need to cover.

Place the remaining 1/2 cup water, the corn syrup, granulated sugar, and salt in a 3-quart heavy-duty saucepan over medium heat. Stir with a wooden spoon until the sugar has dissolved. Attach a candy thermometer to the side of the saucepan. Do not let it touch the bottom of the pan. As the sugar syrup begins cooking, brush down the sides of the pan with a water-moistened pastry brush to prevent the sugar from crystallizing.

Without stirring, brushing down the sides of the pan as needed, cook the sugar syrup until it reaches soft ball stage (when it reaches 235–240°F (113–116°C) on a digital candy thermometer). Remove the pan from heat and let sit for 5 minutes.
Turn the mixer on low speed and slowly pour the hot syrup into the gelatin mixture as the mixer runs. The syrup will be extremely hot, so use caution.

Gradually increase the mixer speed until it reaches high. Whip the mixture for 10–15 minutes, or until it is white, thick, and shiny. If using a handheld mixer, this could take longer. During the last minute of whipping, add the vanilla extract.
Pour/spoon the marshmallow into the prepared pan and smooth out the top with a silicone or offset spatula. Allow to sit, uncovered, at room temperature for at least 6 hours, and up to 48 hours.

Once completely firm, you can cut the marshmallows. To do so, cover a large surface or cutting board with parchment paper. Liberally sprinkle the surface as well as the top of the marshmallow with some of the remaining cornstarch/sugar mixture. Using a sharp knife, loosen the edges of the marshmallow from the pan, and then invert the pan onto the prepared surface. Lift a corner of the pan and use your fingers to help peel the marshmallow away from the pan.

Using a sharp knife, cut the marshmallow into 1.5-inch squares, coating the knife blade with some of the leftover cornstarch/sugar mixture as needed. I find running the blade under hot water and wiping it dry helps to make clean cuts as well. Roll the edges of the marshmallows in the cornstarch/sugar mixture, if desired, so they are no longer sticky.
Store leftover marshmallows at room temperature in an airtight container, with parchment paper between layers, in a cool, dry place for up to 2 weeks.
Adjust oven rack to middle position and heat oven to 375 degrees F.
Line 2 large baking sheets with parchment paper or silpat. Whisk flour and baking soda together in medium bowl; set aside.
Heat 10 tablespoons butter in 10-inch skillet over medium-high heat until melted (about 1-2 minutes).
Once melted, continue to cook while continuously swirling the pan until the butter is a dark brown color and has a nutty aroma (about 1-3 minutes).
Once it’s reached this point, pour butter immediately into a stand mixer (or mixing bowl) and add remaining 4 tablespoons butter beating until all the butter is melted and combined.
To this mixture add sugar, salt, vanilla egg and egg yolk beating until smooth with no lumps.
Let mixture stand 3 minutes, then whisk for 30 seconds. Repeat process of resting and whisking 2 more times until mixture is thick, smooth and shiny.
Gently fold in flour mixture until just combined.
Stir in chocolate chips and nuts if using then stir once more to ensure no flour pockets remain.
Using a cookie scoop, combine 2 scoops (about 3 tablespoons of dough) and roll into a ball placing on the prepared baking sheet 2 inches apart.
Bake cookies 1 tray at a time for 5 minutes, rotate tray and cook for another 5-7 minutes (until edges are lightly browned but center is soft).
Cool on a wire cooling rack until they are firm enough to pick up (about 5-10 minutes) then repeat the above step with second tray of cookies.
Combine the beef Chuck Pot Roast, bell pepper, onion, lime juice, oil, garlic, 1/4 teaspoon salt and black pepper in large bowl. Marinate in refrigerator for 15 minutes or up to 1-1/2 hours.

Heat a large, nonstick skillet over medium-high heat until hot. Spread 1/3 of beef mixture in thin layer in skillet.  Cook until crispy in spots, turning several times, 2 to 3 minutes.  Remove from skillet.  Repeat twice with remaining beef mixture.
Season beef with remaining 1/4 teaspoon of salt.
Serve with rice, black beans and lime wedges as desired.

Alternative Cooking Method

Recipe can be made in a 8-quart Air Fryer. Heat Air Fryer to 375°F. Spread 1/3 of beef mixture in thin layer in basket. Cook until crispy in spots, turning several times, 6 to 8 minutes.  Remove from basket.  Repeat twice with remaining beef mixture. Season beef with remaining 1/4 teaspoon of salt.
Bring a large pot of water to a boil and add 1 Tbsp salt. Cook pasta according to package instructions until al dente. Reserve 1/2 cup of pasta water then drain, cover, and keep warm.
Beat the chicken breasts so that they are even in thickness and season all over with 1½ Tbsp cajun seasoning.

In a large non-reactive skillet*, heat 2 tsp oil over medium-high heat. Once hot, add the chicken and sear on both sides. Turn heat down to low and saute until cooked through and 165˚F on a thermometer. Transfer to a cutting board, slice into thin strips, and cover to keep warm.
In the same skillet over medium heat, saute the butter and garlic for 30-60 seconds or until the garlic is fragrant. Add the diced tomatoes and saute another 2 minutes.
Add in the heavy whipping cream, add remaining cajun seasoning to taste, and parmesan cheese, and bring to a simmer. Season to taste if needed.

Add the sliced chicken and cooked pasta to the sauce and toss until combined and pasta and chicken are warmed through. Add warm reserved pasta water if desired to thin the sauce. Serve with freshly grated parmesan and chopped parsley.
Pat the steak cubes dry with a paper towel.
Season the steak with salt, pepper, and Italian seasoning.
Heat 1 tbsp olive oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat.
Add steak cubes in a single layer and sear for 2–3 minutes per side until browned.
Remove the steak bites from the skillet and set aside.
Reduce heat to medium and add 2 tbsp butter to the skillet.
Add 3 cloves of minced garlic and cook for 30–60 seconds until fragrant.
Return the steak bites to the skillet and toss to coat with garlic butter.
Heat 1 tbsp olive oil in a separate skillet over medium heat.
Add spiralized zucchini and 1 clove minced garlic to the skillet.
Sauté zucchini noodles for 2–3 minutes, tossing gently until just tender.
Season zucchini with salt, pepper, and optional lemon juice or Parmesan.
Serve the zucchini noodles on a plate, top with garlic butter steak bites, and drizzle remaining butter sauce over the top.

In a medium bowl stir together all marinade ingredients. Add the chicken, toss to coat. Cover and chill for 30 minutes.

Ingredients: 
⅓ cup olive oil
juice of 2 limes - 2-3 tablespoons
2 teaspoons minced garlic
2 tablespoons soy sauce
1 teaspoon onion powder
½ teaspoon nutmeg
3 teaspoons allspice
½ teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes
1 tablespoon honey

While the chicken is marinating, combine all salsa ingredients in a bowl and toss to combine. Optional: combine in a blender or food processor and give it a few pulses. Chill until ready to use.

Ingredients:
1 cup diced pineapple
½ onion - diced
handful cilantro - roughly chopped
1 jalapeno - diced, optional
juice of 1 lime
2 teaspoons honey
salt to taste
Use tongs to transfer chicken to a preheated grill or skillet over medium heat (discard marinade) and cook for 6-8 minutes on each side until cooked through.
Serve chicken with pineapple salsa over rice

Preheat the oven to 275 degrees. Using a sharp paring knife, remove the silver skin or membrane (located on the back of the ribs). The knife should help loosen it and then you should be able to pull it off with your fingers. Cut into 3-4 portions. Pat the ribs dry with a paper towel. Combine the brown sugar, paprika, salt, granulated garlic, onion, Chinese five spice, ginger, and white pepper in a small bowl. Coat all sides of the ribs in the rub in a large bowl.
Wrap each portion tightly in aluminum foil and place on a large baking sheet. For baby back, bake for 2-2.5 hours. For st louis, bake 2.5-3 hours.

Once the ribs have almost finished baking, make the glaze. In a small saucepan, heat the sesame oil over medium low heat. Add the garlic and ginger. Sauté for about 2 minutes or until fragrant. Add the brown sugar, honey, soy sauce, vinegar, and red pepper.

Bring the mixture to a boil over medium heat, stirring continuously. Reduce for about 5-7 minutes or until thickened. The glaze will thicken as it cools. If it has not thickened enough after cooling, bring it back to a boil and reduce more.
Unwrap the ribs so the tops are exposed. Brush the ribs liberally with the glaze.
Broil on high, watching closely, for 2-3 minutes, or until lightly charred. Slice into individual ribs and serve with more sauce.
Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C) and lightly grease a medium-sized baking dish.

Season the chicken breasts with garlic salt and place them in the prepared baking dish. Bake for about 45 minutes or until the chicken is fully cooked (internal temperature should be 165°F/74°C and juices should run clear).
Once baked, remove the chicken from the oven and allow it to cool before shredding it into bite-sized pieces. Set it aside.
While the chicken cools, char the tortilla halves over an open flame using metal tongs, cooking them for about 1 minute until lightly puffed.
Pour 1/2 inch of the enchilada sauce into the bottom of the baking dish. Arrange 6 of the tortilla halves in a single layer on top of the sauce.
Layer the dish: top the tortillas with half of the shredded chicken, 1/3 of the cheese, 1/2 of the sour cream, and 1/3 of the remaining enchilada sauce.
Repeat the layers, using the remaining tortillas, chicken, cheese, sour cream, and enchilada sauce.
Once all the layers are assembled, cover the casserole and bake in the preheated oven for 45 minutes.
After baking, allow the casserole to cool slightly before serving.
Preheat the oven to 400°F/205°C.
Add 1 tablespoon of oil to a 3.5 quart skillet.
Saute the onion and garlic over medium heat for 5 minutes or until the onions become translucent and the garlic fragrant.
To the pan layer in pasta, tomatoes, chicken breasts, and crumbled Boursin cheese. Season with salt and add the chicken broth, pushing as much of the pasta below the liquid as you can.
Cover the pan and bake for 40 minutes.

Remove the pan from the oven, and check that the thickest part of the chicken breast with an instant-read thermometer reaches 165°F/75°C. Next, shred the chicken breasts with two forks right in the pan. The liquid in the pan will thicken to create a creamy Boursin sauce as you shred the chicken.
Stir in 3 cups of spinach and sprinkle the top with grated parmesan cheese. Return the uncovered pan to the oven and bake for 10 additional minutes to melt the cheese.
Leftovers and Storage
Place leftovers in an airtight container and refrigerate for up to 3 days.
Reheat leftovers in the oven with a bit of heavy cream to keep the sauce creamy.
I don't recommend freezing it as the cream sauce tends to break and become grainy or watery.

Cut the steak into broad strips and marinate it with all marinade ingredients for at least 4-5 hours.
1.5 lbs flank steak (see note 1)
1 Sazon Goya con culantro y achiote packet
1 tsp adobo seasoning
3 Tbsp sofrito
3 Tbsp vinegar
2 Tbsp garlic, chopped
2 tsp oregano
2 tsp cumin
1 tsp pepper
3 Tbsp olive oil

Heat oil in skillet on medium high heat and quickly sear the steak without marinade on both sides. Once it is browned, add the rest of the marinade along with 1.5 cups of water and cook covered for 5 minutes.

Stir in tomato sauce and sofrito. Mix well. cover and cook about 40-45 minutes, till the meat is tender. Stir occasionally. Adjust water according to the liquid consistency you want. Taste and adjust for seasoning like adobo.
Sauté onion rings in butter and oil till slightly caramelized. Add in sautéed onions to the cooked beef in the last 5 minutes of cooking. (see note 2)
Serve with rice along with tostones and black beans.
Make Tortilla Dough
Add the salt to the warm water and stir together until the salt dissolves.

In a large bowl, use a fork to combine the flour with the oil (or other fat) until it looks crumbly. Pour in almost all of the salty water and stir until a shaggy dough forms. If the mixture seems dry, add a bit more of the water.
When the dough comes together, transfer to a floured work surface and knead until smooth, 2 to 3 minutes.
Cover with a clean dishcloth and leave for at least 15 minutes and up to 2 hours. Resting the dough makes rolling it out easier.

Divide the dough into ten equally sized blobs and shape them into small disks. Use a rolling pin to roll each small disk into 8-inch rounds. The thinner, the better. If you get 9-inch tortillas, don’t worry! We also don’t worry too much about making them perfectly round. (See our video to watch us do it.)

Stack the rolled tortillas with a piece of parchment paper between them. Alternatively, you can roll and cook the tortillas at the same time. Roll one tortilla out, then roll the next tortilla out while it cooks.
Cook Tortillas
Heat a wide, heavy-bottomed skillet over medium-high heat. When it’s hot, add the first tortilla. Within 20 to 30 seconds, you should start to see it puffing up with bubbles.

When the bottom of the tortilla has some brown spots, flip it and cook until the second side is browned in places and the tortilla looks dry around the edges. Each tortilla will take 1 to 2 minutes to cook. If this is taking a long time, increase the heat. If the pan smokes or browns the tortillas too quickly, turn the heat down.
Transfer the cooked tortilla to a dishcloth and cover it, then continue with the remaining tortillas, adjusting the heat as needed.
Marinate the Steak
In a bowl, mix soy sauce, brown sugar, sesame oil, minced garlic, and grated ginger. Add the flank steak, ensuring it’s well coated. Let it marinate for at least 30 minutes.
p id=”instruction-step-2″>2. Cook Rice: Prepare your rice according to package instructions. Set aside once cooked.
p id=”instruction-step-3″>3. Make the Spicy Cream Sauce: In a bowl, combine sour cream, gochujang, honey, and lime juice. Mix until smooth and set aside.
p id=”instruction-step-4″>4. Prepare Vegetables: Chop your choice of vegetables into bite-sized pieces.

p id=”instruction-step-5″>5. Cook the Steak: Heat vegetable oil in a pan over medium-high heat. Remove the steak from the marinade (discard excess marinade) and cook for about 4-5 minutes per side for medium-rare. Adjust cooking time for desired doneness.
p id=”instruction-step-6″>6. Sauté Vegetables: In the same pan, add chopped vegetables. Sauté for about 3-5 minutes until they are tender-crisp.
id=”instruction-step-7″>7. Slice the Steak: Remove the cooked steak from the pan and let it rest for a few minutes. Once rested, slice the steak thinly against the grain.
id=”instruction-step-8″>8. Assemble the Bowls: In serving bowls, place a generous scoop of rice. Top with sliced steak and sautéed vegetables.
d=”instruction-step-9″>9. Drizzle with Sauce: Generously drizzle the spicy cream sauce over the steak and veggies.
d=”instruction-step-10″>10. Garnish: Sprinkle sesame seeds and chopped green onions on top for added flavor and presentation.

Combine all of the marinade ingredients in a gallon ziploc bag, and added the cubed chicken breasts.
1/4 cup Lemon Juice
3 cloves Garlic
1/2 tsp. Salt
1/4 tsp. Pepper
1 Tbsp. Oregano
1 Tbsp. Red Wine Vinegar
Seal the bag, shake to coat the chicken, and marinate at least 20 minutes, or as long as overnight.

Remove the chicken pieces from a marinade and cook in a large skillet with olive oil over medium-high heat for 3-4 minutes on each side. (Alternatively, you can cook the pieces in an air fryer for 11 minutes at 425 for less mess)
Let chicken pieces rest for a few minutes before adding them to the greek bowls.

To make the cucumber salad: combine all sliced salad ingredients and toss to combine.

1 cucumber sliced
1 pint cherry tomatoes
1/2 cup red onion, thinly sliced
1 tbsp lemon juice
1/4 cup olive oil
1 tbsp red wine vinegar
1 tbsp garlic
1 tbsp oregano

whisk all the tzatziki ingredients:
1 cup Nonfat Plain Greek Yogurt
1 tbsp lemon juice
1 tbsp garlic
1/2 tsp salt
1/4 tsp pepper
1 tbsp dill
1/4 cup olive oil
To serve, place the chicken, cucumber salad, tzatziki, and feta cheese in a bowl & enjoy!
